sense.def: a job that is available for someone to do
dictionaryExamples: Tell me if you hear of any vacancies for secretaries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We look forward to meeting you at your ea[r]liest convenience to discuss details, go over our salary and health package as well as any other questions you might have, before starting the procedure of finding suitable candidates for the job vacancies. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a room that is available  in a hotel
dictionaryExamples: Do you have any vacancies?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The hotels have no vacancies, the tourists are everywhere. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: Somewhere that is vacant is available because it is not being used.
dictionaryExamples: a vacant building
The room next to ours is vacant at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You see, we have plenty of vacant rooms so you would not cause any trouble. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: A vacant job is available for someone to do.
dictionaryExamples: The assistant marketing job is vacant - why don't you apply?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, I believe I am suitable for your vacant position. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a period of time to relax or travel for pleasure instead of doing your usual work or school activities
dictionaryExamples: We're taking a vacation in June.
They went to the Bahamas on vacation.
I still have some vacation left before the end of the year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am on vacation, so I don't have to work. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to give someone a special substance to prevent a disease
dictionaryExamples: Have you been vaccinated against polio?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today, ... small kids are vaccinated against most lethal viruses, ... and old people are even vaccinated against the flu. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: an injection of a substance that protects you against a disease
dictionaryExamples: All the children are given a meningitis vaccination.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thanks to vaccination, more and better medicines, and many more doctors, especially in the developing countries; people can now reach up to seventy years of life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a substance that is given to people to stop them from getting a particular disease
dictionaryExamples: Doctors have run out of the flu vaccine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An experiment was recently conducted by the same scientist group to verify if the vaccine works. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: not clear or certain
dictionaryExamples: I have a vague idea of where the hotel is.
He was a bit vague about directions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do not misunderstand me: I greatly enjoyed the conference but it did not give me the satisfaction of having even a vague idea of what I would like to do... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: showing that someone is not thinking clearly or does not understand
dictionaryExamples: a vague expression
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If someone had asked him why, this person would have [given] a vague look, a dismissive shrug of two shoulders and a "oh, just because". Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: in a way that is not clear or certain
dictionaryExamples: I vaguely remember meeting him at Lionel's house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can vaguely remember the decor, and if I tried harder maybe I could remember the taste of the ice-cream. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: based on good reasons or facts that are true
dictionaryExamples: a valid excuse/reason
a valid argument/criticism
My ideas might be different from yours, but they're equally valid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could hardly think of Dr. Quimper as guilty, because every one of the Crackenthorpe family had a valid reason to kill. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: officially or legally acceptable
dictionaryExamples: The ticket is valid for three months.
My passport is valid for another two years.
You need to enter a valid password.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Is this offer valid for the weekends, as well? First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: how true or reasonable something is
dictionaryExamples: We should question the validity of these statements.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This statement is so obvious we almost never question its validity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: an area of low land between hills or mountains, often with a river running through it
dictionaryExamples: the Nile Valley
the Ohio River valley
There was snow on the hilltops but not in the valley.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My home town is situated in a valley. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: Valuable objects are worth a lot of money.
dictionaryExamples: valuable paintings
These antiques are extremely valuable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So as you can imagine, not only is the ring valuable but it also means a lot to me since it makes me remember Brazil! Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: Valuable information, advice, etc. is very helpful or important.
dictionaryExamples: He was able to provide the police with some valuable information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This trip will  allow me to gain valuable knowledge and experience. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: how much money something could be sold for
dictionaryExamples: The new road has affected the value of these houses.
She had already sold everything of value that she possessed.
Cars quickly go down in value.
The value of the dollar depends on the demand in the marketplace for dollars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Well, there was nothing of value in [the suitcase]," my mother remarked, but I was close to tears. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: If something is good value or is a good value, it is of good quality or you think the amount of money you spent on it was right.
dictionaryExamples: This car is a very good value for the money.
Many wines from Austria and South Africa also provide good value.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's real[l]y good value for money, including all equipment, accom[m]odation and food. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: how useful or important something is
dictionaryExamples: The documents are of great historical value.
The necklace had a lot of sentimental value.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was really sad because th[ese] shoes had a lot of sentimental value for me, and they were made of genuine le[a]ther! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the beliefs people have about what is right and wrong and what is most important in life, which control their behavior
dictionaryExamples: family/moral/traditional values
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A tragedy occurs which causes Andrew to rediscover his moral values. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If you accept something at face value because of the way it first looks or seems, you do so without thinking carefully about it.
dictionaryExamples: You can't just accept everything you read in the newspapers at face value.
These results should not be taken at face value - careful analysis is required to assess their full implications.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People are assessed at face value [by] the type of cars they drive. International English Language Testing System; C1; Amharic

sense.def: to consider something important
dictionaryExamples: I've always valued her advice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will learn how other people live and I will also learn to value the things I have. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to judge how much money something could be sold for
dictionaryExamples: The ring was valued at $1000.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Paintings for example are valued by experts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a vehicle that is used for carrying things but that is smaller than a truck
dictionaryExamples: a delivery van
a van driver
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I looked in my mirror and saw [a] white van. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: intentional damage to public or private property
dictionaryExamples: The mayor promised to crack down on vandalism.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Vandalism, for example, is very common, and who are the pretty criminals who do this? Teenagers.  This is clearly caused by boredom. Yes, vandalism stems from the lack of any other suitable activities. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to disappear suddenly
dictionaryExamples: The sun vanished behind the clouds.
The girl vanished while on her way home from school.
We rushed out of the store, but the thief had vanished into thin air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [went after] the thief but he vanished into the crowd. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to suddenly disappear in a mysterious way
dictionaryExamples: He was walking ahead of me on the path and then he just vanished into thin air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fact is that vacations are not problem-solving, and whatever one wants to leave behind does not vanish into thin air, it just lurks in the corner of your mind until the return date. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: when someone thinks they are very attractive and is too interested in their own appearance
dictionaryExamples: Her vanity is staggering.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The vanity of wearing the most fashionable clothes bores my other friend, Kate, to death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: changing often
dictionaryExamples: The sound quality on the recording is variable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By contrast the figure is more variable regarding the other topics. International English Language Testing System; C1; Kurdish

sense.def: a number, amount, or situation which can change
dictionaryExamples: A patient's recovery time depends on so many variables, such as age, weight, and general health.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are too many variables and happiness may also depend on the soci[al] background of a person. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a difference in amount or quality
dictionaryExamples: variations in price/temperature
There was some variation in the quality of the prints.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart from this, there is very little variation in temperature between day and night. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: something that is slightly different from the usual form
dictionaryExamples: It's a variation on the standard apple pie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Big Brother's counterpart, "Lost Story", did really well the first time and a bit less the second time. Still, it is very popular and a variation on this theme, called "Nine people", still does very well today. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: consisting of many different things or types
dictionaryExamples: a varied diet
a long and varied career
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Remember you should always eat a varied diet. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: many different
dictionaryExamples: I left London for various reasons.
They have offices in various parts of the country.
We had various problems on our trip, including a flat tire.
There are various ways of raising money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We played various games and danced too. Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: If things of the same type vary, they are different from each other.
dictionaryExamples: Car prices vary greatly/widely from one state to another.
The samples varied in quality but were generally acceptable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The price of the dishes varies. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to change or to cause something to change
dictionaryExamples: Temperatures vary depending on/according to the time of year.
I try to vary what I eat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To vary the pictures of cultural events, I would recommend [visiting] the Wednesday market, which starts at 8 am. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a container that you put flowers in
dictionaryExamples: a glass vase
a vase of flowers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Beside the bed there [is] a large vase with flower[s]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: extremely big
dictionaryExamples: a vast amount/sum of money
vast areas of forest
The vast majority of students attend public schools.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Among the vast choice of interesting buildings to photograph I can name the "National Portrait Museum", a huge building in renaissance style, [and] the old "Castle of Sforza", built in the eleventh century. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a plant that you eat, for example potatoes, onions, beans, etc.
dictionaryExamples: fresh/frozen vegetables
vegetable soup/curry
fruit and vegetables
In the winter we eat more root vegetables, such as carrots and parsnips.
Raw vegetables contain more vitamins than cooked vegetables.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like eat[ing] fish, vegetables, fruit and sala[d]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who does not eat meat or fish
dictionaryExamples: We feel a lot better since we became vegetarians.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've heard that even the non-vegetarian food is good there, but I'm a vegetarian. Preliminary English Test; B1; Telugu

sense.def: not eating, containing, or using meat or fish
dictionaryExamples: All her children are vegetarian.
vegetarian cooking/food
a vegetarian dish/meal
He decided in college to go vegetarian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you like vegetarian food? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the plants and trees that grow in a particular area
dictionaryExamples: They hacked a path through the dense vegetation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I dream of being the first one to set foot on a white sandy beach, to admire a new kind of vegetation: cranberry bushes, sweet potatoes, wild turkeys, a different climate; how scary and exciting at the same time! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: something such as a car or bus that takes people from one place to another, especially using roads
dictionaryExamples: The driver lost control of the vehicle and hit a tree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes I watch program[s] about cars and other vehicles. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: a piece of material that a woman wears over her head or over her head and face
dictionaryExamples: The bride wore a veil of French lace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Especially, a bride and a groom wear special hats and colorful make-up.  And most brides wear a long veil so grooms can't see their wife's face. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: something that 	hides or prevents you from knowing something
dictionaryExamples: A veil of secrecy surrounded the appointment of the new college president.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Depending on the disposition of those elements within a person, one can turn out to be an angelic soul who radiates trust and happiness, a malevolent spirit hidden under a glamour of niceties; a golden entity, shrouded by a veil of coarseness and bluntness; or a purely evil fiend who e[x]udes despair and malice. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: one of the tubes in your body that carries blood to the heart
dictionaryExamples: the veins in the leg/neck
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you love the sensation of your blood rushing in your veins, your knees trembling slightly and your hair standing [at] attention? Well, I do, and dangerous sports are the thing for me. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: cloth that has a thick, soft surface on one side
dictionaryExamples: a black velvet jacket
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: She was wearing a long black velvet evening gown covered with a pattern of big red roses. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a new activity or business that may involve some risk of failure
dictionaryExamples: a business venture
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They even give vast amounts of people a means of living, and can become very lucrative business ventures. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to leave a safe place and go somewhere that may involve risks
dictionaryExamples: If the snow stops, I might venture out.
He wanted to venture into the mountainous wilderness of the countryside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After having visited some of the more frequented island[s], we decided to venture out to the island of Fourni. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to say or do something when you are likely to be wrong or to be criticized
dictionaryExamples: I wouldn’t venture an opinion about that.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The men and women who could have done something to cut short the chain of events which led to the Second World War had already suffered the First World War, and no one could venture they were in the position of foreseeing the development of a similar war. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a place where a sports game, musical performance, or special event happens
dictionaryExamples: The hotel is an ideal venue for conferences and business meetings.
The stadium has been specifically designed as a venue for baseball games.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Majestic Hotel as the party venue sounds really good but isn't it very expensive? First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a word that is used to say that someone does something or that something happens. For example, the words "arrive," "make," "be," and "feel" are verbs.
dictionaryExamples: a regular/irregular verb
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [T]his book [will] help you to learn basic English, it [teaches] you all the irregular verbs. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: relating to words or the use of words
dictionaryExamples: verbal ability/skills
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found the English lessons very helpful for my students to improve their verbal skills - though we might change the contents to make them more interesting for them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: spoken and not written
dictionaryExamples: a verbal promise/agreement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would expect to receive a reply from your end, either written or verbal, about my complain[t]. International English Language Testing System; C2; Chinese

sense.def: an opinion or decision based on the facts of a situation
dictionaryExamples: City planners think it’s a good idea to ban traffic from downtown streets, but the public’s verdict is that it’s a stupid idea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two or more articles are devoted to famous people and famous political events which took place in Greece, in order to offer a verdict to students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a decision made in a court of law or by a person in authority
dictionaryExamples: a guilty verdict
The jury took nine hours to reach a verdict.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Three months later the verdict was official: he was going to be paralyzed from the waist down. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to prove that something is true, or do something to discover if it is true
dictionaryExamples: It was impossible to verify her statement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Canadian Patent Office Branch will be responsible for verifying if new inventions are truly new or have already been invented somewhere in the world. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: having many different skills
dictionaryExamples: a versatile player/performer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a very gregarious and versatile person whose scintillating and jocular personality makes everybody melt. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: useful for doing a lot of different things
dictionaryExamples: a versatile tool
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Internet today is the most versatile tool in so many ways. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: one of the parts that a song or poem is divided into
dictionaryExamples: I only know the first verse of the poem.
Each verse was sung as a solo and then everyone joined in on the chorus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I was so puzzled that when I tried to sing, I couldn't remember a word of the verse I had written. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: one form of something that is slightly different from other forms of the same thing
dictionaryExamples: An English-language version of the book is planned for the fall.
The original version of the film is much better.
a new/updated version
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Who has never said that the original book was better than the film version? First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: someone's description of what has happened
dictionaryExamples: Her version of the accident was completely different from that given by the driver of the other car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I do not know your source of information, but not only did he/she provided you with many untruthful details, the style of the article also shows a biased version of the event. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that one team or person is competing against another
dictionaryExamples: Tomorrow's game is Newcastle versus Arsenal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In May, we held a students versus teachers football match and the great game ended up 2-2. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: used to compare two things or ideas, especially when you have to choose between them
dictionaryExamples: private education versus state education
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Alien" versus "200 Warriors" - I am not a professional critic, but here is my little review: The best film I have ever watched is most likely the "Alien" by Ridley Scot[t]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: pointing straight up from a surface
dictionaryExamples: a vertical line
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The vertical axis i[n]dicates the different years while the horizontal axis illustrates the money spent in millions. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: used emphasize an adjective or adverb
dictionaryExamples: Thank you very much.
She was very pleased.
He's very kind.
The situation is very serious.
Think about it very carefully before deciding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My teacher is very nice. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: not good, tall, happy, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The film wasn't very good.
He doesn't sing very well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My college is not very big. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to a large amount or degree
dictionaryExamples: Thank you very much for the flowers!
I like her very much.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like Bradford very much. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: used to emphasize a noun
dictionaryExamples: This is the very book I've been looking for all month.
You're the very person we need for the job.
He found the missing paper at the very bottom of the pile.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You cannot infringe individual liberties and ban the purchase of cars - it would go against the very fabric of modern society. International English Language Testing System; C2; Romanian

sense.def: something you wear that is like a jacket with no sleeves
dictionaryExamples: My grandfather always wore his vest buttoned up.
a sweater vest
Be sure you have a life vest for each person in the boat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And [he] has too show how much he earns: he only wears top brand watches, shirts and vests, with colors profoundly studied and well combined. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone whose job is to give medical care to animals that are ill or hurt
dictionaryExamples: Helen is training to become a vet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sorry Mr. Smith but I'[ll miss] tomorrow's class as I have to go to the vet with my dog. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: someone who has a lot of experience doing a job or activity
dictionaryExamples: She's a 20-year veteran of TV news broadcasting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the school where I work as an English teacher there are two veteran teachers of English. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: someone who was once a member of one of a country's military organizations
dictionaryExamples: a veteran of World War II
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But even now I can recollect my unwillingness to get involved in parades, to join the veterans, military men, soldiers who were really proud of having a rare opportunity to feel a cog in a big wheel. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: going through or stopping at a place on the way to another place
dictionaryExamples: The train to Philadelphia goes via Baltimore.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two years ago I traveled to Canada via Italy. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: using a particular machine, system or person to send or recieve something
dictionaryExamples: Reports are coming in via satellite.
I'll send the details via e-mail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hate shopping via [the] internet. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: effective and able to be successful
dictionaryExamples: a viable alternative to nuclear power
an economically viable plan
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is a question that demands reasonable answers and viable solutions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: something bad that someone often does
dictionaryExamples: His virtues far outnumber his vices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My children would always know that they are loved and accepted in spite of their vices and not only for their virtues but just because they are my children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: used for referring to the opposite of what you have just said
dictionaryExamples: Never use indoor lights outside and vice versa.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The piles of cash are not far away from any celebrity and we all know that time equals money and vice versa. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Bulgarian

sense.def: violent and dangerous
dictionaryExamples: a vicious attack on a child
a vicious dog
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was a real, vicious murderer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: intended to upset someone
dictionaryExamples: a vicious rumor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One advantage with this school that rose above the others, was the fact that there was virtually no cruel bullying or vicious teasing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a continuing unpleasant situation, created when one problem causes another problem which then makes the first problem worse
dictionaryExamples: Many people get trapped in a vicious circle of dieting and weight gain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So we could say that it becomes a vicious circle. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: someone who has suffered the effects of violence, illness or bad luck
dictionaryExamples: victims of crime
The children are the innocent victims of the fighting.
The new drug might help save the lives of cancer victims.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His wife was his last victim. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: when you win a game, competition, election, fight, war, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Phoenix managed a 135-114 victory over Denver.
Grant won/achieved/gained a comfortable/easy victory over Cooper in yesterday's match.
This result is a victory for democracy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were all celebrating their victory with a gorgeous dinner. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a short film that can be watched on television, a computer, a camera, etc.
dictionaryExamples: music videos
video sites
They showed me their wedding video.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it because it has a camera to make videos. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a film, television program, etc. recorded on a long, narrow, magnetic strip, or the recorded strip itself that is inside a rectangular plastic container
dictionaryExamples: He just used to stay in and watch videos.
We had the whole series on video.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [O]n that chan[n]el you have the chance to watch many videos of your favourite singer, and learn about their news. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: a short video recording that you can see on a website
dictionaryExamples: The website has several video clips of celebrity interviews.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It shows how a band or a singer do their video clips. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a game in which you make pictures move on a screen
dictionaryExamples: He plays a lot of video games.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We played cricket, and we also played video games. Key English Test; A2; Singhalese

sense.def: the things that you can see from a place
dictionaryExamples: On a clear day, the view from the top of the mountain is amazing.
The rooftop restaurant has a spectacular view  across the bay.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The view from the window of my room is the best one. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: your opinion
dictionaryExamples: We have different views about/on education.
In my view, her criticisms were justified.
I take the view that everyone should be free to decide for themselves.
It's my view that everyone should have the right to choose.
We had a friendly exchange of views.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, in my view, spending time in a city is more sensible. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: how well you can see something from a particular place
dictionaryExamples: We had a great view of the procession.
Don't stand in front of me - you're blocking my view of the stage.
She turned a corner, and disappeared from view.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In a few seconds, he disappear[ed] out of my view. First Certificate in English; B2; Vietnamese

sense.def: because of
dictionaryExamples: In view of recent events, we have decided to cancel the meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In view of what happened, I would advise you not to try to mislead people like this [again]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a position from which something can be seen
dictionaryExamples: The house was hidden from view behind a wall.
He turned the corner and the harbor came into view.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The animal disappeared as unexpectedly as it came into view. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

blocks.phrase: take a dim view of sth

sense.def: to disapprove of something
dictionaryExamples: Most bosses take a dim view of long lunches.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's nearly impossible to see him strolling or strutting, in fact he is always striding; he is also one of the few men who still speaks with an accent, despite the fact that he perfectly knows that someone could take a dim view of him for this. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to watch something
dictionaryExamples: They were able to view the city from a helicopter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People sit in p[a]latial cafes and restaurants to view the beauty of that "lazy river." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to have a particular opinion about someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The policy is so far viewed as a success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is of course the argument of many young people: that they live in a society that op[p]resses them, where they cannot express themselves freely and where, whatever they do or say, they are viewed as "punks" or "idiots" by adults. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: someone who watches a  television program
dictionaryExamples: Millions of viewers will be watching the last show of the series.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He's an extraordinary person and TV viewers will love him because of his good sense of humor and his honesty. First Certificate in English; B2; Romansch

sense.def: a way of thinking about a situation
dictionaryExamples: From his viewpoint the action seemed entirely justified.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a student, I feel concerned [about] the traffic issue and I asked some people about their viewpoints on the two proposals. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a group of stores, houses, and other buildings that is smaller than a town
dictionaryExamples: a small fishing village
Many people come from the surrounding villages to work in the town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My grandmother lived in a village and I often went there. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a plant with a twisted stem that climbs things or grows along the ground
dictionaryExamples: The wall was covered in vines.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After follow[ing] the walking path through the vines at Canon-Fronsac you could climb the Canon Mountain to have a view all over the region. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a sour liquid that is used in cooking, often made from wine
dictionaryExamples: red wine vinegar

sense.def: to not obey a law, rule, or agreement
dictionaryExamples: Countries that violate international law will be dealt with in court.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All three points strongly violate the regulations and immediate action is required. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: when someone tries to hurt or kill someone else
dictionaryExamples: an act of violence
A number of people were killed in the violence.
Violence against women has increased in recent years.
The recent outbreak of violence in the region is very disturbing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today, it is important that children and teenagers do something with their free time and do not get in contact with criminality and violence. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: extreme force and energy, especially of something causing damage
dictionaryExamples: Such was the violence of the explosion that three buildings collapsed.

sense.def: involving violence
dictionaryExamples: a violent crime
a violent protest
His movies tend to be very violent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some say that television can affect people in bad ways and sometimes causes violent incidents. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: using force to hurt or attack someone else
dictionaryExamples: a violent criminal
He shouts a lot but I don't think he's ever been physically violent with her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now Mary knew what happened at Jamaica Inn and it was very dangerous for her because her uncle was a violent man. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: sudden and causing damage
dictionaryExamples: a violent explosion/storm
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The violent storm was rocking the ship back and forth. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: in a way that involves violence
dictionaryExamples: He often behaved violently and they were terrified of him.
He claimed to have been violently assaulted while in prison.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes they behave violently because of their [imprison]ment. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a wooden musical instrument with four strings, which you hold against your  neck and play by moving a bow across the strings
dictionaryExamples: I've been learning the violin for the last four years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobb[ies are] reading and playing the violin. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: Virgin land, forest, etc. has not been used or damaged by people.
dictionaryExamples: 50 acres of virgin woodland
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The balance of nature is threatened by the construction of luxurious hotels in the middle of virgin forests. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: someone who has never had sex
dictionaryExamples: She was a virgin at the time of her marriage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This was Anne-Marie, 27 years old and fairly attractive.  But still a virgin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: using computer images and sounds that make you think an imagined situation is real
dictionaryExamples: a virtual art gallery online
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I go far away from my family and other people and have virtual relationships. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: almost a particular thing or quality
dictionaryExamples: Ten years of  bad government had brought about the virtual collapse of the country's economy.
War in the region now looks like a virtual certainty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However the growth of our cities and townships co[up]led with an exponential increase in traffic and facilities have transformed these areas into virtual no-go zones International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: almost
dictionaryExamples: I've virtually finished.
Their twins are virtually identical.
That wine stain on my shirt has virtually disappeared.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Virtually everyone today can go out and buy their own personal computer. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: in a way that uses computer images and sounds that make you think an imagined situation is real
dictionaryExamples: Nowadays all these things can be experienced virtually.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also have the possibility of making new friends: I can connect to a special site which will enable me to [meet people] virtually. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when a computer produces images and sounds that make you think an imagined situation is real
dictionaryExamples: virtual reality games
virtual reality software
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Magnificent scientific pro[j]ects are done by computers, [as well as] daily shopping, com[m]unication with people in other parts of the world, games, getting any kind of information and, soon, virtual reality! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a program that is secretly put onto a computer in order to destroy the information that is stored on it
dictionaryExamples: My computer has been acting strangely, and I suspect it's a virus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That document was a "virus" and erased all my documents [o]n my computer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an infectious organism too small to be seen that causes disease, or an illness that it causes
dictionaryExamples: a flu virus
I don't know exactly what's wrong with her - I think it's some kind of virus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My "friend" Pat told everybody that my brother died and that he died because he got a virus - that's why I didn't have friends because all the people thought that I had the virus too. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: an official mark in your passport that allows you to enter or leave a particular country
dictionaryExamples: We traveled to Argentina on a tourist visa.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tomorrow I am not going to attend [the] class because I have to apply for my visa at 9.00. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: able to be seen
dictionaryExamples: You should wear something light-colored when you're cycling at night so that you're more visible.
The fire was visible from several miles away.
There are few visible signs of the illness that kept her in the hospital for so long.
The comet should be visible to the naked eye.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He waited curiously for her to become visible through the fog which seemed to have gotten denser in the last few seconds. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: obvious or noticeable
dictionaryExamples: She is a highly visible environmental spokesperson.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After about three months I noticed a visible improvement. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: in a way that can be seen
dictionaryExamples: He was visibly upset.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, it is my firm conviction that if the authority reconsiders some of its regulations and take urgent steps, [the number of] unemployed people will be visibly reduced. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an idea or image in your mind of what something could be like in the future
dictionaryExamples: a vision of a better society
We see in his novels his grim vision of the future.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All in all, I think you must write a new report to apologize for having been so pessimistic and having given such a bleak vision of this Festival. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the ability to see
dictionaryExamples: He has poor vision in his left eye.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her hands were sweating and her vision had become a blur because of the tension in the air. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the ability to make plans for the future that are imaginative and wise
dictionaryExamples: As a leader, he lacked vision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A man of vision, Eleftherios Venizelus played a significant role in the history of my country, as in his time it became, with [few] changes, what it is today. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to go to someone's home and spend time with them
dictionaryExamples: Will you visit me when I'm in the hospital?
We have friends coming to visit this weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She visits her parents once a week. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: to go to a place and spend a short amount of  time there
dictionaryExamples: We visited a few galleries while we were in Chicago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a very nice place with a lot of shop[s] and museum[s] to visit, like the "Louvre" for example. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi

sense.def: to look at a website
dictionaryExamples: There's the usual invitation to visit their website.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want more information or you want [to] see photos about [the] art class, visit our website: www.artclass.com. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: when you visit a place or a person
dictionaryExamples: the President's visit to Argentina
I think I'll pay a visit to the hairdresser's while I'm in town.
We had a visit from the building inspector last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The problem is that my mother arranged a visit [to] the doctor, and after that [to] the dentist. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: someone who visits a person or place
dictionaryExamples: Ben, you have a  visitor here to see you.
The museum attracts large numbers of visitors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I did [a] very good meal for all of my visitors. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: relating to seeing
dictionaryExamples: The film has some powerful visual effects.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It also provides a clear idea of how people's lives were in a particular period by showing us the visual images of that time. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: necessary or extremely important
dictionaryExamples: Tourism is vital to the country's economy.
The kidney plays a vital role/part in the removal of waste products from the blood.
It's absolutely vital that you follow the instructions exactly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you don't mind I would like to ask you some vital questions. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: energy and strength
dictionaryExamples: At 48, he still projects an image of youth and vitality.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Full of joy and vitality, enjoying all the changes around her, Alice was as happy as she had never been before. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: in a very important way
dictionaryExamples: Safety at work is vitally important.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being able to use the computer and the Internet successfully is vitally important in today's society but it will be even more important in the future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: one of a group of natural substances that you need to be healthy
dictionaryExamples: a vitamin pill
Oranges are full of vitamin C.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the one hand, we eat a lot of sweet [or] fat food, which lack[s] vitamins. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: A vivacious person, especially a woman, is full of energy and enthusiasm.
dictionaryExamples: She is extremely vivacious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, there are a few qualities, which would attract me to someone, they are not essential, though: I would rather have someone as a friend who is vivacious and gregarious than someone who is withdrawn and retiring. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: Vivid descriptions or memories produce strong, clear images in your mind.
dictionaryExamples: He gave a very vivid account/description of life in Havana.
I still have a very vivid memory of the evening.
She has a very vivid imagination.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Each memory is still so vivid. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: A vivid color is very bright.
dictionaryExamples: She was wearing a vivid pink shirt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Students would like to have some vivid colors or pictures on the walls but the best solution would be to repaint the walls. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: in a vivid way
dictionaryExamples: I vividly remember my first day at school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She could vividly remember the last time he hurt her, only then it was with a razor. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: all the words you know in a particular language
dictionaryExamples: a large/big/limited vocabulary
Reading helps to expand your vocabulary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure I will improve my vocabulary and English Grammar. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Turkish

sense.def: all the words that exist in a language, or that are used when discussing a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: Computing has its own specialist vocabulary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is true because the several authors of the magazine use a significantly advanced vocabulary while writing in Greek, which is sometimes difficult even for a native Greek to understand. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a strong feeling that you are right for a particular type of work, or a job that gives you this feeling
dictionaryExamples: He knew that teaching was his true vocation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was a teacher, seeing teaching as his vocation, [and] nothing could boost his confidence as much as excellent students and successful [results]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: Vocational education and skills prepare you for a particular type of work.
dictionaryExamples: The school offers both vocational and academic courses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, learn[er]s can choose a different path, for example [a] technical, vocational or academic one. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the sounds that are made when people speak or sing
dictionaryExamples: She has a very loud/quiet/soft voice.
a clear/deep voice
a high/low voice
You could tell from her voice that she wasn't happy.
She lowered her voice to a whisper.
You'll have to raise your voice  if you want to be heard in here.
Could you please keep your voices down?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her voice is so clear and she has the nicest eyes which I've ever seen. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to become unable to speak, often because of an illness
dictionaryExamples: She had a bad cold and was losing her voice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I immediately became agitated and at the precise moment of my speech I lost my voice completely. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to speak loudly and angrily to someone
dictionaryExamples: Even when he was angry with his children, he never raised his voice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not every au-pair family is pleasant. And believe me, mine was giving me hell on earth. [...] After I returned home I took some time to learn not to freak out when someone raised his voice and eventually I started to see my time in Germany as a great [lesson in] life. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: to say what you think about a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: Opponents also voiced concern about potential traffic produced by the project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And in the end they voiced their wishes to re-unif[y] Germany. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a mountain with a large hole at the top, which sometimes explodes and produces hot, melted rock and smoke
dictionaryExamples: an extinct/active volcano
Erupting volcanoes discharge massive quantities of dust into the atmosphere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I think that a good place to go is Santorini, a beautiful island which has a volcano. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a game in which two teams use their hands to hit a ball over a net without allowing it to touch the ground
dictionaryExamples: They played volleyball on the beach.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies are playing volleyball and watching TV. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the level of sound produced by a television, radio, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Could you turn the volume up/down, please.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After we went to the disco and we danced together, but the volume of the music was too high to talk! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the number or amount of something, especially when it is large
dictionaryExamples: I was put off by the volume of work involved.
The volume  of traffic in the city is causing problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, marketing volume is rapidly increased in Internet business, according to one of [the] major newspaper[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a book, especially one of a set
dictionaryExamples: a new dictionary in two volumes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This book which I adored as a child, and as a matter of fact, one which I often come back to, comprises seven volumes, each giving a vivid account of the adventures that the Pevensie siblings, Lucy, Edmund, Susan and Peter, encounter in the magical land of Narnia. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If something speaks volumes, it makes an opinion, characteristic or situation very clear without the use of words.
dictionaryExamples: She said very little, but her face spoke volumes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It remains to be seen whether the effect of stem cells when applied to humans would be the same, but the achievements speak volumes about the fact that stem cells may one day turn a new [page] in many people's lives and let them get rid of that humiliating label of a "disabled person." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: If you do something voluntarily, nobody has forced you to do it.
dictionaryExamples: She left voluntarily.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After he had himself discharged voluntarily from the hospital, he drove up to the cliff, [and] left his car there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: Voluntary work is done without being paid and usually involves helping people.
dictionaryExamples: She does voluntary work for Doctors Without Borders.
voluntary organizations
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I did voluntary work for a whole year in 1998 in Britain. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: a person who does something, especially helping other people, willingly and without being forced or paid to do it
dictionaryExamples: a Red Cross volunteer
The charity relies on volunteers to run the office and answer the telephones.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well the concert was Friday night and I went there with the Red Cross volunteers, did you know I'm one of them? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to offer to do something without being asked or told to do it
dictionaryExamples: Rob volunteered to look after the kids.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of my classmates, Maria, has volunteered to talk about the different courses and summer activities that the school offers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: If someone vomits, the food or liquid that was in their stomach comes up and out of their mouth.
dictionaryExamples: He felt sick all day and then he suddenly started to vomit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people do feel headaches and vomit if they watch television for extensive number of time. International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu

sense.def: to show your choice or opinion in an election or meeting by doing something such as writing a mark on an official piece of paper, using a special machine to record your choice, or putting your hand up
dictionaryExamples: Who did you vote for?
The union voted against going on strike.
The city council has voted to reject the development plan.
She was too young to vote in the national election.
The committee voted on the proposal and accepted it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then the audience and the ju[dg]es voted w[hi]ch country was the best. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: when someone shows their choice or opinion in an election or meeting by doing something such as writing a mark on an official piece of paper, using a special machine to record their choice, or putting their hand up
dictionaryExamples: He lost the election by twenty votes.
The motion was approved, with 25 votes in favor and 7 against.
She cast her vote  for the Democratic Party candidate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [T]he one who get[s] the most votes will get 1000 Baht as first prize. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: a way of making a decision by asking a group of people to vote
dictionaryExamples: We called a meeting in order to take a vote on the issue.

sense.def: when someone is officially allowed to vote
dictionaryExamples: In some countries women still don't have the vote.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Women acquired the vote only 70 years ago. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to vote
dictionaryExamples: More than 30,000 citizens cast their votes in the last city election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the day of the General Elections came, no woman cast her vote [for] James and he lost his seat to a man from a minority party, not even the man representing the Labour Party. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a person who votes or who has a legal right to vote, especially in an election
dictionaryExamples: Of course, tax cuts are usually popular with the voters.
Voters are interested in issues that affect their pocketbooks, he said.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Low taxes seem to be the most important issue for this party and it's voters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to make a serious promise or decision
dictionaryExamples: They vowed (that) they would never forget her kindness.
I've vowed never to go there again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most definitely Yiannakis' plan had not worked out and after that episode he vowed that he would never set foot in a stadium again. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a serious promise or decision
dictionaryExamples: marriage vows
I made a vow that I would write to him once a week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The vows (and the rings) are exchanged after a short speech given by the priest. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: a speech sound that you make with your lips and teeth open, shown in English by the letters a, e, i, o, or u
dictionaryExamples: A short vowel is a short sound as in the word "cup."
A long vowel is a long sound as in the word "shoe."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [In the game,] he let the student[s] cho[o]se [a] vowel or consonant. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: a long journey, especially by ship, or in space
dictionaryExamples: Cook's voyage to Australia
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, I have a good command of French and I speak English fluently, which might be also useful during the voyage around the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: easy to hurt or attack physically or emotionally
dictionaryExamples: She was a vulnerable sixteen-year-old.
The troops are in a vulnerable position.
He's more vulnerable to infection because of his injuries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore they are vulnerable to being twisted by their environment, by events, or by more manipulat[ive] minds. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean
